title: 107_hr2715
content: The Act is titled the "Rim of the Valley Corridor Study Act". It includes findings related to the study. The Congress finds that the greater Southern California metropolitan region, the second largest urban concentration in the US, lacks sufficient park and recreation lands per population. This deficiency deprives residents of health benefits and increases the risk of crime. The Rim of the Valley Corridor surrounding the San Fernando and La Crescenta valleys offers various benefits like reduced crime, lower social tension, and increased educational opportunities for urban populations. It provides scenic, environmental, recreational, educational, scientific, and economic assets to Southern California, deserving increased protection for public benefit in the future. The Rim of the Valley Corridor, including the San Gabriel Mountains and adjacent areas, contains the endangered Mediterranean chaparral ecosystem and unique ecotones. The San Gabriel Mountains within the Angeles National Forest are managed for watershed, recreational, and habitat values, not for commercial exploitation. Private lands in the corridor are crucial for scenic and environmental purposes. The Rim of the Valley Corridor, including the San Gabriel Mountains, holds significant environmental and recreational value. Efforts to protect these resources have been hindered by a lack of financial and technical support from the Federal Government, despite progress made by local governments and the State of California. The Rim of the Valley Corridor is being studied for inclusion in the Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area. The Secretary of the Interior will conduct a special resource study of the Rim of the Valley Corridor in Southern California to evaluate its national significance and feasibility of becoming part of the Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area. The study will follow criteria for potential inclusion in the National Park System. The Secretary will consult with the Rim of the Valley Corridor and Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area Advisory Committee during the study. Establishment of Advisory Committee. The Rim of the Valley Corridor and Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area Advisory Committee is established to advise the Secretary of the Interior on a study and recommend boundaries for a new recreation area that reflects the Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area. The Committee established to advise the Secretary of the Interior on a study and recommend boundaries for a new recreation area including the Rim of the Valley Corridor and Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area. The Committee will submit a recommendation with maps depicting proposed boundaries within 365 days of its first meeting. Public participation will be provided. The Committee, consisting of 24 members appointed by the Secretary of the Interior, will provide opportunities for public participation in recommending boundaries for a new recreation area. Members include representatives from local governments in the vicinity of the recreation area. The city councils of Westlake Village, Malibu, Calabasas, Burbank, Glendale, La Canada-Flintridge, Pasadena, Sierra Madre, South Pasadena, Santa Clarita, Moorpark, and the board of supervisors of Los Angeles county represent unincorporated communities within their jurisdictions. The East Rim of the Valley Trail Corridor will be represented by various officials, including the Superintendent of the Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area, the Supervisor of the Angeles National Forest, the Superintendent of the Angeles District of the State of California Department of Parks and Recreation, the Director of the Santa Monica Mountains Conservancy, and a representative of the Rancho Simi Recreation and Park District. The Committee will have representatives from different park districts, including Conejo Recreation and Park District and Pleasant Valley Recreation and Park District. The Committee will select a chairperson and vice chairperson from its members, who will serve without compensation but will be reimbursed for necessary expenses. A quorum of 13 members is required for conducting business, and the Committee will terminate upon the submission of the special resources study by the Secretary of the Interior. The Committee will terminate upon the submission of the special resources study by the Secretary of the Interior to Congress.
